awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Single photon imaging by solid-state photon sensor array spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to facilitate more rapid diagnostics with better accuracy. The project develops new optical technologies for medical and biotechnology systems, with higher sensitivity to detect smaller and fewer molecules. The target markets are companies in medical diagnostic instruments, biological research instruments, microscopy, and high-resolution optical instruments. The proposed device will consist of custom-designed arrays to replace older technologies, as well as fully configured optical units offering new capability to existing products. By increasing the speed of light detection devices and creating a new generation of detection arrays, this technology will enable a new generation of optical detection-based diagnostic devices.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project develops a new light detection sensor array for spectroscopy instrumentation applications. The project incorporates "Differential Geiger Mode" techniques directly into the read-out circuitry, reducing the photon detection dead time by over 2 orders of magnitude. These specialized integrated circuits are placed within the sensor array itself to achieve high speed (GHz) signal collection. A novel cooling arrangement will be implemented by applying on-board thermoelectric cooling and integrating it with a specialized housing to ensure the optimal environment for high performance sensor operation and operational longevity.  This project will advance a new generation of sensor arrays capable of functioning at the single photon level with high speed signal collection.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The phase I funding for Miftek Corporation was targeted toward solving a fundamental problem within devices that detect very small amounts of light. Typically, these devices are single units such as photomultiplier tubes or avalanche photo diodes. However, for extremely sensitive or very fast applications, current sensors are not adequate.  There are several reasons for this. First, they are too slow to measure very fast events such as single photon pulses. Second, many new applications in the biodetection domain are demanding multiple sensor arrays to accommodate spectral (wide wavelength) signal collection.  There are several aspects of this technology development that are leading edge in terms of the intellectual property developed which is likely to have significant societal impact as noted below.

In order to determine the practical manufacturing ability of a 42-channel sensor array, our goal within the confines of the Phase I award, was to prove that this 42-channel sensor array was a viable technology by manufacturing at least an 8-ch version and demonstrating its function.

Figure 1 shows the base design of the chip we ended up with. This base can accommodate all 42 sensors as well as the electronics. We tested different methods for cooling the chip as it does generate significant heat. We utilized a thermal cooling technology that was effective for the Phase I project. A modification of this component will be necessary for Phase II since we need to reduce the temperature to at least -30 deg C and currently with a low-cost device we were able to achieve -16 deg C.

We also designed the sensor unit for a full 42-channels within the Phase I award, but for proof of principle we only used 8 sensors and 8 sets of electronics to prove functionality. This design is shown in Figure 2. Some important achievements that were made during the Phase I award was a demonstration that we could achieve 2.5 gigacycles which is extremely fast and this provides strong evidence that our 42 channel sensor array, with 0.6 ns sensing time will become a very important technology with potential for integration into many instruments.

The Phase I NSF award enabled Miftek to develop the fundamental proof of principle that a 42-ch single photon sensor array could be designed and manufactured and function. This technology is being proposed to be integrated into a very high parameter biological detection instrument focused on fluorescence detection. We propose in Phase II, to continue development of the 42-ch chip and the associated electronics which is specialty electronics to accommodate the very high-speed nature of these new sensors. By combining the sensor array with a visible spectrum spectrometer, this technology will become the center piece in a very high parameter fluorescence detection instrument.

The impact this technology will have is significant. It will create the first fully digital high parameter fluorescence detection instrument that is commonly known as a flow cytometer. These instruments are commonly used today in biological and medical research laboratories. They can also be used in hospital laboratories for monitoring cancer, infectious diseases and a variety of other syndromes.

With the innovative technology funded within this Phase I NSF award, we will see significant improvements in biological detection technologies as the type of sensor under development will eventually become integrated into many different instruments. This will lead not only to new discoveries but also to a cost reduction in many high technologies used in the field of immunology, virology, microbiology and pathology. Other areas that could have impact are industrial applications for analysis of pharmaceuticals and vaccines where small particles are evaluated. We also believe that there will be impact in high level microscope systems and high-level physics applications. These new technologies are necessary for the USA to maintain superiority in very high level detections and sensor applications.
